introduction.title: Basic laws for electrical circuits
introduction.p: This two-page worksheet was generously donated to the sample article by Virgil Pierce at a CuratedCourses workshop in August2018. It has default (skinny) left and right margins, but we have specified longer top and bottom margins, with the top being the larger of the two.

theorem.title: Ohms Law
theorem.p: The current through a resistor is proportional to the ratio of the Voltage to the Resistance I = \frac{V}{R} Or for our purposes I R = V

theorem.title: Kirchoffs Current Law
theorem.p: The sum of the currents in a network meeting at a point is zero. \sum_{k=1}^n I_k = 0

example.title: Kirchoff's Current Law
example.p: For the circuit below I_1 + I_2 = I_3 .

theorem.title: Kirchoffs Voltage Law
theorem.p: The sum of the voltages around any closed circuit (or subcircuit) is zero. \sum_{k=1}^n V_k = 0

introduction.p: Kirchoffs Current Law and Kirkoffs Voltage Law combined with Ohms Law gives for any circuit of resistors and sources a linear system that may (or may not) determine the currents.
